newsitem.title: KYRGYZSTAN: Kyrgyz electricity firm sees privatisation plan.
newsitem.headline: Kyrgyz electricity firm sees privatisation plan.

text.p: Kyrgyzstan's national electrical firm Kyrgyzenergoholding has forwarded its privatisation plan to the government and the scheme envisages attracting a strategic investor, possibly foreign, the company said on Wednesday.
A news release described a four-step privatisation process for the company, which is a net exporter of electricity to Central Asian neighbours Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.
The scheme would first involve setting up a joint stock company called Kyrgyzenergo and holding a specialised voucher auction for citizens.
Kyrgyzstan's voucher privatisation, in which citizens can swap vouchers for shares in enterprises, ends on June 30.

The next stage would entail selling off social infrastructure and small hydro-power stations and creating state joint-stock companies out of individual power stations and generation and transmission units.
The last stage would see a tender to attract a strategic investor, possibly foreign.
The state would retain a controlling share.
Foreign investment is key to the small, former Soviet republic's sector, and a state official told Reuters at least $650 million was needed to keep the national power grid in order.
Another $4 billion was needed to finalise construction of two hydro-power stations and around $70 million to renovate electricity transmission lines.

Kyrgyzstan, with 19 hydro-electric power stations and two thermal facilities, produces 12-14 billion kilowatt hours a year, making use of just nine percent of its huge energy potential, which is estimated at 142.5 billion kilowatt/hours.
